dt: {bc}changed or modified especially to make a correction or improvement

dt.t: Dig a hole … . Amend the backfill soil with 50 percent peat, set the plant in the hole, fill in with the {wi}amended{/wi} soil, and mulch well around the plant.

shortdef: changed or modified especially to make a correction or improvement

dt: {bc}to make {d_link|emendations|emendation} in (something, such as a text)
{bc}to change or modify (something) for the better {bc}{sx|improve||}
{bc}to alter formally by modification, deletion, or addition

pt: {sc}correct{/sc} {sc}rectify{/sc} {sc}emend{/sc} {sc}remedy{/sc} {sc}redress{/sc} {sc}amend{/sc} {sc}reform{/sc} {sc}revise{/sc} mean to make right what is wrong. {sc}correct{/sc} implies taking action to remove errors, faults, deviations, defects.
{sc}rectify{/sc} implies a more essential changing to make something right, just, or properly controlled or directed.
{sc}emend{/sc} specifically implies correction of a text or manuscript.
{sc}remedy{/sc} implies removing or making harmless a cause of trouble, harm, or evil.

pt.t: set out to {it}remedy{/it} the evils of the world

pt: {sc}redress{/sc} implies making compensation or reparation for an unfairness, injustice, or imbalance.
{sc}amend{/sc} {sc}reform{/sc} {sc}revise{/sc} imply an improving by making corrective changes, {sc}amend{/sc} usually suggesting slight changes
, and {sc}revise{/sc} suggesting a careful examination of something and the making of necessary changes.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}amender{/it}, modification of Latin {it}emendare{/it}, from {it}e, ex{/it} out + {it}menda{/it} fault; akin to Latin {it}mendax{/it} lying, {it}mendicus{/it} beggar, and perhaps to Sanskrit {it}mindā{/it} physical defect
shortdef: to put right; especially : to make emendations in (something, such as a text)
to change or modify (something) for the better : improve
to alter especially in phraseology; especially : to alter formally by modification, deletion, or addition
